accessibility.title: Accessibility statement for 'Appeal a benefit decision' service
accessibility.titleIba: Accessibility statement for 'Infected Blood Compensation decision' service
accessibility.description: This accessibility statement applies to the website available at https://www.appeal-benefit-decision.service.gov.uk/ that allows users to submit, track and manage a benefit appeal online.
accessibility.descriptionIba: This accessibility statement applies to the website available at https:// www.gov.uk/guidance/appeal-an-infected-blood-compensation-decision/ that allows users to submit, track and manage an infected blood compensation decision appeal online.

manages.managedBy: This website is run by HM Courts and Tribunals. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website, so we have designed it to be accessible. For example, that means you should be able to:
manages.ability1: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
manages.ability2: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
manages.ability3: navigate most of the website using just a keyboard
manages.ability4: navigate most of the website using speech recognition software
manages.ability5: listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
manages.ability1Iba: change colours, contrast levels and fonts using browser or device settings
manages.ability2Iba: zoom in up to 400% without the text spilling off the screen
manages.ability3Iba: navigate most of the website using a keyboard or speech recognition software
manages.ability4Iba: listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
manages.managedByExtra1: We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.
manages.managedByExtra2: AbilityNet has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.

howAccessible.title: How accessible this website is
howAccessible.para1: Parts of this website are not fully compliant. This website is periodically tested for accessibility by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC), to ensure it meets the required level of accessibility for compliance with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, using a combination of technical auditing and feedback from users with accessibility needs. The latest accessibility audit, undertaken by the DAC, has identified parts of this website which are not fully compliant. All issues and recommendations within the DAC report are being addressed.
howAccessible.para1Iba: We know some parts of this service are not accessible, and the issues are listed under Non-compliances. We plan to carry out further testing and address the issues as soon as we can.

whatToDo.title: Feedback and contact information
whatToDo.para1: If you need information on this website in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read, audio recording or braille then email: HMCTSforms@justice.gov.uk or phone:
whatToDo.para2: We’ll consider your request and get back to you within 10 working days.

reportingProblems.title: Reporting accessibility problems with this website
reportingProblems.para1: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of this website. If you find any problems not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, email: HMCTSforms@justice.gov.uk or phone:

enforcement.title: Enforcement procedure
enforcement.para1: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint, contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS).

contactus.title: Contacting us by phone or visiting us in person
contactus.para1: We provide a text relay service for people who are D/deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
contactus.para2: Our offices have audio induction loops, or if you contact us before your visit we can arrange a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter.
contactus.para3: Find out how to contact us using the contact details above.

technical.title: Technical information about this website’s accessibility
technical.para1: HMCTS is committed to making its website accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.

compliance.title: Compliance status
compliance.para1: This website is partially compliant with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.1 AA standard.
compliance.para1Iba: The website is partially compliant with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.2 AA standard.

nonAccessible.title: Content that’s not within the scope of the accessibility regulations
nonAccessible.para2: Some of our PDFs and Word documents are essential to providing our services. For example, we have PDFs with information on how users can access our services, and forms published as Word documents.
nonAccessible.para3: The accessibility regulations do not require us to fix PDFs or other documents published before 23 September 2018 if they’re not essential to providing our services.
nonAccessible.para4: Any new PDFs or Word documents we publish will meet accessibility standards.

iba.title: Non-accessible content
iba.description: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
iba.subTitle: Non-compliance with the accessibility regulations
iba.para1: On some pages a user can tab to text elements, when they shouldn't be able to. This may cause confusion for keyboard users as they would expect tabbing to go only to interactive elements. This fails against WCAG 2.2 success criterion 1.3.2. (meaningful sequence).
iba.para2: On some pages, links are not unique, so screen reader users may have difficulty understanding the purpose of each link. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.4.4 (link purpose).
iba.para3: Some web pages have multiple heading level 1’s, so people using a screen reader may be confused about the main content on the page. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.4.6 (headings and labels).
iba.para4: Some web pages have missing heading levels, so some screen reader users may miss information on the page. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.4.6 (headings and labels).
iba.para5: On some pages, there are missing or broken aria-labels, so labels may be communicated incorrectly to screen reader users. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 2.4.6 (headings and labels).
iba.para6: On some webpages, the error message link does not move focus to the field where the error was made, so some users may lose where they are on the page. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 3.2.2 (on input).
iba.para7: On some pages, there is no hint text to indicate a specific format for information to be entered, so some users may not understand what information they are required to provide. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 3.3.2 (labels or instructions).
iba.para8: On some pages, the error message does not provide a link to the field where the error was made so, keyboard users may not be able to tab to the field directly from the error message. This fails WCAG 2.2 success criterion 3.3.3 (error identification).

toImprove.title: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
toImprove.para1: This website is continually tested using accessibility software internally and externally. Any new features which are introduced are also tested. Following the audit conducted by the DAC in September 2023, we are urgently fixing content which fails to meet the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines AA standard.
toImprove.para1Iba: We plan to fix the issues listed under non-compliances by 21 March 2025.
toImprove.para2Iba: We also plan to work with the internal HMCTS accessibility testing team to arrange a full WCAG 2.2 audit covering a wider range of assistive technologies in February 2025.

preperation.title: Preparation of this accessibility statement
preperation.para1: This statement was originally prepared on 30th September 2020. It was last reviewed 5th December 2025.
preperation.para1Iba: This statement was prepared on 30th September 2020 and it was last reviewed on 5th December 2025.
preperation.para2: This website was last tested on 15th August 2025. The test was carried out by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC). Issues are currently being resolved, after which this statement will be revised.
preperation.para2Iba: This website was last tested on 19th December 2024. The testing was carried out by the internal HMCTS accessibility testing team, who carried out a high-level review using Wave, Keyboard and Google Lighthouse.
